Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Nephrotoxic Effects of Sevoflurane

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in an intensive care unit setting.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing surgery requiring general anesthesia.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received sevoflurane, while the control group received isoflurane.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the nephrotoxic potential of sevoflurane compared to isoflurane.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) within 48 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the sevoflurane group and 100 to the isoflurane group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the sevoflurane group and 97 in the isoflurane group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of AKI was higher in the sevoflurane group (37.5%) compared to the isoflurane group (10.7%), with a mean difference of 26.8% (95% CI 15.2 to 38.4; p = 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included nephrogenic diabetes insipidus in 7% of the sevoflurane group and 2% of the isoflurane group.

Funding.evidence: Funding: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
